awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Long Distance Trade and Social Complexity
awd_abstract_narration:
Mr. Christopher Schwartz will conduct research to examine how people draw on networks of distant interaction and exchange in the process of placemaking, and how that process changes over time. The archaeological record offers particularly relevant insight into this topic through its ability to trace the developmental trajectories of settlements and changes in interaction networks over time. This research primarily focuses on one object, the scarlet macaw (Ara macao), and its influence far outside of its endemic homeland. This dissertation project will employ a novel framework, combining biogeochemical methods with a material culture theoretical perspective to explore how past people acquired, treated, and deposited ritually significant, non-local objects at three regional centers in the past. More broadly, this project will improve anthropological understandings of the extent to which societies separated by great distances interacted in ways that had transformative local influences - a form of pre-modern globalization. Additionally, this project will enhance relationships and infrastructure for research by creating research partnerships amongst Arizona State University, the Hopi Tribe, the Museum of Northern Arizona, and the National Park Service. Because this project directly studies sacred animal remains and addresses questions of relevance to the Hopi community, this project was formulated in direct consultation with the Hopi Cultural Preservation Office.

This dissertation research will examine several dimensions of scarlet macaws that brought them significance in the pre-Hispanic US Southwest and Mexican Northwest (SW/NW). Despite the distant natural habitat of scarlet macaws, which is hundreds of kilometers to the south in southern Mexico and Central America, their importation, exchange, and sacrifice appear to have played integral roles in the establishment of SW/NW regional centers from 900-1450 AD. This time period saw large-scale migration, rapid population aggregation, and an expansion of long-distance exchange relations in regional centers at Pueblo Bonito (900-1150 CE) in northeastern New Mexico, Wupatki (1085-1220 AD) in north-central Arizona, and Paquim (1200-1450 AD) in northwestern Chihuahua. Radiogenic strontium isotope analysis of scarlet macaw skeletal tissue and comparative contextual analyses applied through a material histories framework will be used to (1) discern whether scarlet macaws discovered in the SW/NW were imported from Mesoamerica or raised locally, (2) characterize the treatment and deposition of scarlet macaws at Pueblo Bonito, Wupatki, and Paquim, and (3) identify patterns of continuity or change in acquisition, treatment, and deposition of scarlet macaws over time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Exchange is a fundamental human behavior. While today people are capable of exchanging information over great distances in seconds, in the past, long-distance exchange of ideas and objects required far greater efforts. By virtue of their circulation over great distances, we know that distantly transported objects held significance to past people, but this significance can be difficult to identify in archaeological contexts. This project explored the long-distance circulation and treatment of one object with a long-term history of significance to people living in the U.S. Southwest and Mexican Northwest (SW/NW); the scarlet macaw (Ara macao). Although scarlet macaws are native to eastern and southern Mexico and seen in the wild almost 1,500 kilometers away, they have been encountered at archaeological sites throughout the SW/NW and remain important to Indigenous communities living in this region today. 

This project developed a novel framework, drawing on theory from material culture studies and merging biogeochemical and archaeological methods, to explore the significance of scarlet macaws to Indigenous communities of the SW/NW, which begins around 900 CE and continues to present day. The major goal of this work was to better define and characterize the acquisition, treatment, and deposition of non-local scarlet macaws at SW/NW archaeological settlements and in doing so inform our understanding of the transformational social impacts of acquiring and keeping these birds. To do so, we explored three major lines of inquiry: (1) were scarlet macaws found in the SW/NW raised locally or acquired from non-local settlements?; (2) how did past people treat and deposit scarlet macaws at major settlements in the SW/NW?; and (3) was there continuity or change in patterns of acquisition, treatment, and deposition of scarlet macaws over time and space in the SW/NW? We evaluated these questions at three relatively well-populated regional centers in the SW/NW: Pueblo Bonito (900 to 1150 CE) in the Chaco Canyon region of northwestern New Mexico, Wupatki (1080 to 1250/1275 CE) in the Flagstaff area of Arizona, and Paquimé (1200 to 1450 CE) in the Casas Grandes region of northwestern Chihuahua.

By conducting radiogenic strontium isotope analysis on scarlet macaw bone tissue and local environmental baseline samples, we found that all of the sampled scarlet macaws from Pueblo Bonito and Wupatki had been raised locally. At Paquimé, most scarlet macaws had been raised locally, but there was a more variable pattern of macaw acquisition demonstrated by people also acquiring scarlet macaws from elsewhere within the Casas Grandes region and from extra-regional locales. By examining published archaeological reports and datasets from Pueblo Bonito and Paquimé, and collections from Wupatki at the Museum of Northern Arizona, we found there to be substantial differences in macaw treatment and deposition at these sites. At Pueblo Bonito, people kept up to 14 macaws in an aviary-like room and buried them whole in the earliest-built areas of the site, whereas at Wupatki, very few birds had been buried whole; the few that had were given burial treatments similar to humans. Hundreds of scarlet macaws had been deposited at Paquimé, suggesting that they would have been pervasive, with their bright feathers and loud calls seen and heard everywhere at the large settlement, and in death buried alongside the people that cared for them. From a genealogical perspective, macaw keeping practices shifted substantially over time to meet the ideas and needs of the communities that cared for them, with similarities in acquisition and treatment at Wupatki echoing practices first observed at Pueblo Bonito. The hundreds of macaws found throughout the site of Paquimé suggest that it operated on a completely different scale.

Overall, we find that throughout the region scarlet macaws are associated with the social process of placemaking and that their ties to distant lands and special characteristics (e.g., large size, bright multi-colored feathers, ability to replicate human speech) would have set settlements capable of acquiring them apart from the experience of living other places. The local impact of scarlet macaws would have been transformational, albeit measurably different from the impacts of these birds at settlements to the south in Mesoamerica where they range freely. This project was formulated in consultation with the Hopi Cultural Preservation Office and discussions with members of the Cultural Resource Advisory Team contributed to understanding patterns observed in the archaeological record. The diverse human interactions resulting from long-distance exchange and the negotiation of place illustrated in this study continue well past 1450 CE and into contemporary times, where artistic and oral traditions, Macaw and Parrot Clan knowledge, ceremonies and dances, and emergence stories continue to be passed down to generations of Hopis and other Indigenous communities throughout the SW/NW.
